history.content:
I don't know enough about your interests or goals to answer this very well, perhaps, but here are a few things that I can think of that you might consider if you're choosing to take either/both:

  • If you're hoping to get involved in deep RL research, understand what kinds of problems people are working on in the area, and get a feel for what it's like, the lectures, reading, and in particular the project for 285 might be a good opportunity to do that.
  • 210A is a demanding course. For me personally, this class was much more work than any EECS upper div. Comparatively, the homeworks for 285 are less frequent and and more straightforward.
  • Part of the reason I'm not sure how to answer your question is the courses seem to fulfill very different roles; if you want strong statistics fundamentals for a future research career, 210A can help you with some of that. 285 is much more applied in some sense, involving more implementation, algorithms, current research directions, etc. 

If you're motivated and interested, both are great courses -- it depends on what you're looking for. If you have more specific questions, I might be able to give some thoughts in followups.

children.subject:
On your first point, if you're just looking for a light workload, CS 285 is the way to go. But, CS 285 is the kind of course where you only get out as much as you put in, so if you aren't putting in a lot of time, you won't get as much out of the course. Stat 210A, on the other hand, was a significant workload for me, but I learned a ton!

If I compare them to specific courses, my personal experience was that CS 285 was about CS 61A/CS 188 workload and possibly less depending on how much effort you want to put into the course, and Stat 210A was a even higher workload than CS 189 workload (it was probably the highest workload course I've taken). 

On your second point, I wouldn't say knowledge of analysis or measure theory is necessary for 210A (I took 210A without either background). But, you might want to get a refresher on doing proofs and also read through the first chapter of Theoretical Statistics by Keener before you start.

Thanks so much, student answer. That helps a lot.

For my interests, I think I'm more interested in theoretical statistics than I am in RL, since I'm interested in applications to social science and econ. In terms of 285, I'd like to learn more about RL as a part of my research interest in online machine learning.

I guess the workload is also a concern for me, since I don't want too much work while I'm applying to grad school. I don't know much analysis or measure theory, so I'd have to do some catch up at the start.

Relevant courses I'd taken were EECS 126, Math 104, and I'd estimate linear algebra knowledge to about the level of Math 110. Had also taken CS 189 but that seems less relevant here. Especially if you're confident in your probability, I think that should suffice, but be aware that you might have to go and learn/review a good amount of material along the way.

@Anon Poet What was your math/stat background before taking Stat 210A? Thanks for the detailed response! I've taken CS 189, Stat 134, and Math 104 (using Ross), but not sure if that is enough preparation for the course.

history.content:
Hi all, I'm a senior interested in ML. I've taken 189 and 127 and enjoyed them, so I wanted to take a more high level class.

I was given enrollment codes for 210A and 285, but I wanted to get some advice from people who might have taken them in the past.
history.subject: Stat 210A vs CS 285
